title: Vlatko Andonovski introduced as new coach of U.S. women’s national team
text:
“All of the talented coaches and players that have come before have built a legendary tradition of excellence,” Andonovski said, “and I’m committed to working very hard to continue to move this program forward.”

AD

Andonovski will begin his tenure with friendlies against Sweden on Nov. 7 in Columbus, Ohio, and Costa Rica three days later in Jacksonville, Fla. He will name his first roster this week.

AD

The next major competition for the top-ranked Americans is next summer’s Olympics in Tokyo. Qualifying in the Concacaf region will take place in January and February.

Andonovski won two National Women’s Soccer League titles in five years with FC Kansas City before guiding Reign FC, which is based in Tacoma, Wash., to the semifinals each of the past two seasons. He was voted the league’s coach of the year in 2013 and 2019.

His Reign players included attacker Megan Rapinoe and midfielder Allie Long from the U.S. squad. Defender Becky Sauerbrunn played for him with Kansas City. Several World Cup players from other countries have played for him in the NWSL.

AD

“He has this unique ability to really get the best out of every player. His tactical flexibility and knowledge is tremendous,” Rapinoe said. “Even being in the NWSL [which is considered perhaps the best women’s league in the world], I don’t think he is really able to put on his full arsenal of what he knows.”

AD

The search for Ellis’s replacement was spearheaded by Kate Markgraf, a former U.S. defender who in August was named general manager of the women’s program. Markgraf said she spoke with several candidates before narrowing the list for a second round of conversations.

She then chose two finalists. Laura Harvey of the Utah Royals is believed to be the other.

AD

“The one thing that is consistent when you watch any of Vlatko’s teams — and especially when he was without some of his key players — they always liked to have the ball,” Markgraf said. “They are always very sound defensively, and they attack creatively.

“Vlatko was the best fit with his experience with elite players, how he sees the game, how he coaches the game and manages players, and his overall personality and ability to take on a job of this magnitude.”

AD

With a small gap between the World Cup and Olympics, Andonovski said he would rely heavily on the core group that this summer won consecutive world titles for the first time in the program’s golden history.

AD

However, he said, “It doesn’t mean we are not going to expand the roster and the player pool.”

During a five-game victory tour, Ellis called up several players who were not on the World Cup roster, including Washington Spirit midfielder Andi Sullivan. The Olympic squad, however, would have only 18 players, five fewer than the World Cup team.

Andonovski plans to conduct an identification camp in December with non-World Cup players.

He said he has spoken with forward Alex Morgan, who last week announced she is pregnant. Due to give birth in the spring, Morgan is angling to return for the Olympics.

AD

Beyond personnel decisions, Andonovski will have to adapt to a women’s brand of the game that is expanding rapidly around the world. The United States remains a dominant figure in the sport, but many countries, including Spain and the Netherlands, are catching up.

AD

“The competition for us is only going to get more intense,” USSF President Carlos Cordeiro said. “The years ahead won’t be a time for resting on our laurels but for reaching even higher.”

Andonovski said he is prepared for the increasing challenges and the perennial high expectations he must meet.

“I wouldn’t necessarily say change,” he said of his plans for the team. “I would say evolve.”

As a player, Andonovski was a pro for six years in North Macedonia, the Balkan nation formerly part of his native Yugoslavia. He then moved to the United States in 2000 to play indoor soccer in Wichita; Kansas City, Mo.; Philadelphia; and Stockton, Calif., before entering the indoor coaching ranks with Kansas City.

AD

AD

“Now when I look back, I wouldn’t have believed it,” he said of landing the U.S. job. “Once I started coaching, in the back of my mind, there was always that thought if the opportunity presents itself, I would love to coach this team.”

Andonovski takes the helm as the U.S. players remain locked in a legal battle with the federation over equal pay. The sides are scheduled to go to court May 5.

He said he does not believe it will cause a distraction.

“I am very respectful of the drive the players have,” he said. “In fact, that is something positive for me because it will translate to the field. I have no doubt once they step on the field they will be focused on what is important at that time. They’ve proved that in the past, and I have no doubt they are going to do that in the future.”

AD

Cordeiro said he did not want to comment on the specifics of the case, citing pending litigation. The sides remain in contact in hopes of reaching a resolution before they meet in court.

AD

Even though mediation in August failed, he said: “We are still very committed to resolving this in a fair way, but at the end of the day that requires compromise. … I sincerely hope we can put this behind us soon enough. Give us some more time, but hopefully we are heading in that direction.”

description: Andonovski replaces Jill Ellis, who stepped down after leading the Americans to another World Cup title this year.
